Human mortality rates due to infectious diseases from drug-resistant bacterial strains is becoming an epidemic in our society. Currently, the development of new, expensive and more effective treatment processes and medications have stemmed from the impotence of antibiotics due to misuse and/or improper administration. This has consequently created a range of short- and long-term side effects in patients. On the other hand, nanoparticles have been shown to exhibit antimicrobial potency towards various types of pathogens due to their size and cell damaging abilities through various mechanisms. Unlike antibiotics, which are administered to treat diseases and infection in patients, nanomaterials provides an interesting opportunity to limit microbial growth prior to human infection. This has led to the development of engineered antimicrobial materials, targeting different applications with nanoparticles as the active antimicrobial agents. Hence, we critically reviewed the recent progress achieved in the use
ealthcare of engineered nanomaterials for antimicrobial applications and the mechanism that make them highly effective. Applications in water treatment, healthcare and facility substrates, alternative food packaging, and antifouling coatings have been given special attention due to their relevance as media through which diseases are easily spread. Likewise, drawbacks and knowledge gaps in nanomaterial solutions for antimicrobial materials are discussed.

It has been shown that a nanoparticle with a size of around 1–10 nm has outstanding antimicrobial activity efficiency due to the increased contact area with bacteria [7]. Therefore, nanoparticles with increasingly smaller dimension, for example, metal nanoparticles with biocidal properties including silver, copper oxide, zinc oxide, titanium dioxide, zero-valent iron; carbon nanotubes, and bio-nanoparticles like chitosan nanocomposites are part of a class of antimicrobial nanoparticles which are currently under extensive investigation [12]. These nanoparticles show excellent biocidal activities toward a range of microorganisms without the concern of developing resistant strains [9].
The application of antimicrobial nanoparticles and their mechanism against microbes have been well investigated from a biological and healthcare viewpoint and extensively reported in the literature. Here, we reviewed the current advances in antimicrobial nanoparticle applications from a materials engineering standpoint in very relevant application platforms such as healthcare, food packaging and water treatment. Furthermore, niche areas such as coatings for architectural paints, antifouling, clothing, personal care (soaps and cosmetics), and air filtration/quality are also reviewed. The review extracted current advances in antimicrobial nanoparticle engineering and their applications while identifying knowledge gaps and indicating future research directions.

The mouth is a host to various bacteria and can act as incuation sites when not properly cared for. In dentistry, there is lways a concern about the infection of the exposed underlying tisue, particularly after a dental procedure. Antibiotics are typically sed to combat and prevent infection of the area. However, these ntibiotics can have some adverse effects on the liver and in some ases can cause the patient to react. During dental surgeries and econstruction, irrigants such as hypochlorite and chlorhexidine re commonly used to clean, flush and disinfect areas susceptible o infection [26]. However, these irrigants are temporary fixes, as hey are eventually washed away, dried up or soaked up by gauze, eaving no protection against a host of bacteria. Likewise, they can e potentially harmful to the host as they are known for tissue estruction on a cellular level [26,27].

Recently, Rodrigues et al. evaluated silver nanoparticles in aqueous solutions as a potential irrigant [29]. Silver nanoparticles (AgNP) was chosen due to its capability of limiting the activities of an array of both gram positive and negative bacteria by binding to their cell walls and releasing silver ions [30]. Several concentrations of AgNP solutions were tested against E. faecalis. Results from their study suggested that a concentration of 94 ppm of AgNP was enough in preventing the growth of E. faecalis. When compared to hypochlorite, it was found not to be effective at reducing biofilms formation at short irrigation times of approximately 5 min. However, at longer times (15 to 30 min), there was no significant difference between the antibacterial activities on the biofilms of both. Other studies have shown that longer contact time of antimicrobial nanoparticles such as AgNP with well-developed biofilms is required to produce significant antimicrobial activities especially at very low concentrations [31,32].
Similar studies using AgNP and zinc oxide (ZnO) nanoparticle aqueous solutions at concentrations of 1 and 26%, respectively, demonstrated comparable results to chlorhexidine and hypochlorite irrigants. Contrarily, there was hardly any effect on the reduction of the biofilm at lower concentrations of AgNP (0.1%).
Overtime, the growth and development of biofilms can occur on the surface where common irrigants were used while the presence of nanoparticles embedded on the surfaces will hinder further growth. These results show that though AgNPs are expensive, at low concentrations in aqueous solutions without the addition of any surfactants nor additive, they can be equally effective at preventing bacterial growth while still being cost competitive with limited concern for cell damage of the healthy tissue. Furthermore, the particles can remain within the cavities to maintain antimicrobial activities, leading to rapid recovery and healing of the surrounding tissue. Though permanently embedding nanoparticles in the body is not the best choice nor practice, it has been shown that over time, they can be excreted from the body through the hair, urine, and feces when ingested [33].
2.2. Applications in dental composites
Dental composites, especially from polymer resin and inorganic fillers are widely used in dentistry as fillers for cavities, reconstruction of artificial teeth and other structures within the mouth. These materials have to be resilient, durable and able to withstand the rigorous activities and environment in the mouth such as varying pH and mechanical abrasion during chewing and contact with food. Therefore, coupling agents are used to chemically modify the surface of the filler, thereby allowing for the formation of chemical bonds with the cured polymer resin. Without this, leaching can occur over time [34]. This ensures that there is no leaching of any component of the dental material while also improving its physical properties and durability [35].
However, the growth of bacteria can form biofilms on these surfaces and result in more plaque accumulation in comparison to other surfaces such as enamel. Antimicrobial nanoparticles (ANPs) such as ZnO embedded within dental composite materials have demonstrated antibacterial activities and led to a reduction in the growth of bacterial biofilms against S. sobrinus as much as 80% [36]. Potent and well-known ANPs such as Ag nanoparticles have been studied and shown to be effective when incorporated into acrylic polymer material for denture applications with minimal toxicity towards humans [37].

4.3. Water antifouling using antimicrobial nanoparticles decorated filtration membranes
Filtration membranes enable the purification of water with high suspended solid contents. Nanofiltration is a proven alternative for the purification of seawater. Unfortunately, filtration operations are prone to the formation of biofilms on the surface of the membranes over time, which compromises the performance of the membranes. Moreover, when polymeric membranes that are typically polyamide-based membranes are used, they display sensitivity to the utilization of biocidal chemicals such as chloride. A strategy to avoid the proliferation of microorganisms over the filtration membranes is to decorate the surfaces of the membranes with nanoparticles which can exert antimicrobial activity. Such approaches provide opportunities to accomplish both filtration and disinfection of water simultaneously [204,205].

Some of the methods for incorporating nanoparticles onto polymeric filtration membranes are blending, dip coating, grafting polymerization and interfacial polymerization [206]. Among these methods, graft polymerization is advantageous since it can covalently bond nanoparticles to filtration membranes, avoiding their loss during operation and provide the desired biocide activity. The use of nanoparticles for water disinfection has been largely explored as a promising alternative in securing water supply. However, there are challenges to be considered in pursuing the large-scale implementation of these technologies in the replacement of existing ones. The direct addition of ion leaching nanoparticles to contaminated water needs continuous replenishing to compensate the spent nanoparticles leaching from their surface. This represents an economical challenge to the viability of this alternative method, given the high cost and difficulties in synthesizing nanoparticles on a large scale. This could be alleviated to a certain extent, if the recovery of nanoparticles is further developed. For example, the use of supported nanoparticle systems which could be separated by magnetic separation is a promising alternative that is expected to grow in the near future.
Using light triggered nanoparticles for water disinfection and nanoparticle-decorated filtration membranes has a major constrain in the consumption of significant amounts of energy during the process. Solar based photocatalytic processes are alternatives being researched to decrease energy dependence of the photocatalyzed water disinfection. However, these processes would require unrealistic surface areas for achieving a satisfactory yield. Moreover, the dependence of the process on solar light makes it unviable during the night or in locations where sunlight is scarce.
Hence, these processes need the development of new photovoltaic materials capable of converting solar light to electricity with higher efficiencies than current existing ones. In spite of all the challenges that remain unaddressed, a few commercial products for water disinfection based on nanoparticles are available on the market. However, these products are intended for treating low volumes of water; mostly for domestic consumption and single users [280]. Thus, it seems that enabling nanoparticle mediated large scale water disinfection still has a long way to go before reaching a mature and efficient state, capable of displacing existing water disinfection methods in water treatment plants.
The use of biologically sourced and sustainable antimicrobial nanoparticles are the way forward as environmental awareness and preservation is of great concern. Chitosan, a nanoparticle typically extracted from the shell of crustaceans has sparked the interests of researchers and has been extensively studied due to its nontoxicity to human cells, bio-sourced and renewable, making it an attractive antibacterial material. Chitosan NPs will be an excellent candidate for marine coatings due to their non-toxicity to marine life. Studying and improving the antidiatom and antibacterial effect of Chitosan NPs for marine coating applications will be a relevant addition to the body of knowledge.

metadata.abstractText: Human mortality rates due to infectious diseases from drug-resistant bacterial strains is becoming an epidemic in our society. Currently, the development of new, expensive and more effective treatment processes and medications have stemmed from the impotence of antibiotics due to misuse and/or improper administration. This has consequently created a range of shortand long-term side effects in patients. On the other hand, nanoparticles have been shown to exhibit antimicrobial potency towards various types of pathogens due to their size and cell damaging abilities through various mechanisms. Unlike antibiotics, which are administered to treat diseases and infection in patients, nanomaterials provides an interesting opportunity to limit microbial growth prior to human infection. This has led to the development of engineered antimicrobial materials, targeting different applications with nanoparticles as the active antimicrobial agents. Hence, we critically reviewed the recent progress achieved in the use ealthcare of engineered nanomaterials for antimicrobial applications and the mechanism that make them highly effective. Applications in water treatment, healthcare and facility substrates, alternative food packaging, and antifouling coatings have been given special attention due to their relevance as media through which diseases are easily spread. Likewise, drawbacks and knowledge gaps in nanomaterial solutions for antimicrobial materials are discussed. © 2019 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
